Waldomiro Mon, 26 Apr 2004 08:50:43 -0300
> I have an unit of code which [shows] a message when [an error
> occurs].

> Then the user needs to click ok to make the message [disappear].

> I'd like to [automate] the click, so the user doesn't need to be
> there when JUnit is testing my application.

> Is there anyway to do that ?

Yes. In fact, there are several way to automate the testing of Java
GUIs, both testing their state and automating UI events. These
approaches can be divided into 2 categories:

* Real testing. There are now many tools that will allow you to
  *really* interact with Java GUIs (e.g. query, click on, type in),
  and to drive that testing from JUnit. For more details, consult

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/java-gui-testing/

  The tool I recommend is Abbot

http://sourceforge.net/projects/abbot

  which allows one to write code like

> // find an instrumented text
> TextTester tt = TextTester.getTextTester();
> Text idText = tt.getInstrumentedText("idText");
> assertTrue("idText not enabled", tt.getEnabled(idText));
> assertTrue("idText not writable", tt.getEditable(idText));
> // type in it
> tt.actionEnterText(idText, STRUTS_MAPPING_ID);

> // find an uninstrumented Button
> ButtonTester tt = ButtonTester.getButtonTester();
> Button finishButton = null;
> try {
>   finishButton = DefaultWidgetFinder.findButtonByTextTitleShell(
>       FINISH_BUTTON_TEXT,
>       ACTIONMAPPING_GENERIC_REGIONPAGE_TITLE,
>       ourShell
>   );
> } catch (WidgetNotFoundException nf) {
>   notReached(nf.getMessage());
> } catch (MultipleWidgetsFoundException mf) {
>   notReached(mf.getMessage());
> }
> assertTrue("finishButton is disabled", bt.getEnabled(finishButton));
> // click on it
> bt.actionClick(finishButton);

  Note the above code tests an SWT UI, but Abbot is even better for
  Swing. (For one thing, it has a newer, more usable idiom for
  finding that we haven't yet implemented on the SWT side.)

* Bogus testing. Instead of actually interacting with your UI, create
  API that pretends to do that, e.g.

Jonathan Oddy Mon, 26 Apr 2004 17:41:37 +0100
>   public void testDoSomething()
>   {
>     boolean [] warningShown[0] = { false };
>     // override your message
>     SomeClass c = new SomeClass()
>     {
>       protected void showWarning() 
>       {
>         warningShown[0] = true;
>       }
>     }
>     // perform the work you want to test...
>     c.doSomething();
>     // check it
>     assertTrue(warningShown[0]);
>   }

  This approach was born of necessity in the days before one could
  drive UIs from heavyweight, native tools like WinRunner. Like any
  "mock" approach, it can be "good enough," but is no substitute for
  real testing.
